body_html:
In general, all TensorFlow intermediate tensors disappear after a run, except:

  1. If you put it in a Variable, and mark it "trainable=False". I would recommend this for now.
  2. Push into a queue. However, the current queue implementation doesn't work with GPU yet. There are design discussion to change that.
  3. A semi-experimental feature called partial_run. Only touch this if you feel very brave. :)

    tensorflow/tensorflow/python/client/session_test.py

    Line 1285 in 2098b9a

    res = sess.partial_run(h, r1, feed_dict={a: 1, b: 2})

If you put it in a Variable, and mark it "trainable=False". I would recommend this for now.
Push into a queue. However, the current queue implementation doesn't work with GPU yet. There are design discussion to change that.
A semi-experimental feature called partial_run. Only touch this if you feel very brave. :)

body:
In general, all TensorFlow intermediate tensors disappear after a run, except: 
1. If you put it in a Variable, and mark it "trainable=False". I would recommend this for now. 
2. Push into a queue. However, the current queue implementation doesn't work with GPU yet. There are design discussion to change that. 
3. A semi-experimental feature called partial_run. Only touch this if you feel very brave. :) https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/2098b9abcf20d2c9694055bbfd6997bc00b73578/tensorflow/python/client/session_test.py#L1285
